comments.commentBody: Trading prisoners is part of war.  Paying ransom is not.

The Administration is flip flopping.  It will trade 5 terrorists from Guantanamo (after ransom is refused) for an army soldier who possibly deserted but will not pay a random for an established journalist.
Trading prisoners is part of war.  Paying ransom is not.

The Administration is flip flopping.  It will trade 5 terrorists from Guantanamo (after ransom is refused) for an army soldier who possibly deserted but will not pay a random for an established journalist.
What a thoughtless comment at this moment of tragedy and horror.
What a thoughtless comment at this moment of tragedy and horror.

With respect to the author's first paragraph, HP and Google Plus clearly enacted these policies primarily to monetize the public's time on their sites. When last I checked, which was some time ago, HP was devolving into a notel-motel for intellectually lazy Johnny one note malcontents, bleh.

Next, for the many instances when the trolls are obviously paid hacks, it's difficult to see how this constitutes discourse (aaahhh, corporate personhood). Trolls also seem to have the effect of reducing sites to meetingplaces of like-minded people - not exactly a wellspring of vigorous debate. Most importantly, there is a tremendous gulf of difference between uncivil speech and acts of stalking or harassment. or inciting violent behavior.
Could you please comment on what you think should have happened to the terrorists and their leaders who bombed the King David Hotel?  Should they have been rooted out and killed?
Could you please comment on what you think should have happened to the terrorists and their leaders who bombed the King David Hotel?  Should they have been rooted out and killed?

As GWBush said, shockingly to journalists, during his Iraq war - "sometimes profit trumps peace".  This is one of thousands of other symptoms of a very sick (capitalist) society.  Whenever there's a price or profit on something/someone - corruption, abuse, conflict of interests exists.

As GWBush said, shockingly to journalists, during his Iraq war - "sometimes profit trumps peace".  This is one of thousands of other symptoms of a very sick (capitalist) society.  Whenever there's a price or profit on something/someone - corruption, abuse, conflict of interests exists.

That France and other European nations pay ransom reflects, I think, their basic disagreement with US policy in the Middle East. "It's not our war" they reason and after all, millions of dollars are but a pittance in a national budget. But of course it IS their war, like it or not and it is deeply immoral to choose who lives and who dies on the basis of nationality. If the French want to ransom for hostages' lives, let them ransom for all lives and not just those of their citizens. Otherwise stop paying at all and recognize that in the end their will be fewer hostages and fewer murders.

Otherwise stop paying at all and recognize that in the end their will be fewer hostages and fewer murders.

I appreciate why some wish we would pay, although I am certain we must not do it.   The flood gates of hell would open up - and lets be honest, the money is used to finance their war against civilization.  These chickens, financed by those EU nations that pay, will be coming home to roost soon enough, as expat fighters return home as vigilant jihadists ready to wreck havoc on us all.  The longer we pretend there is some civilized solution to this, the more innocent people will have to die at their hands, until we finally decide the childrens heads being cut off look enough like our own children and we act.  There is no room for moral equivocation here.  The peace lovers need to understand we can deal with ISIS now in Iraq and Syria or later at home.  We need to act swiftly, with overwhelming force, and make the strike catastrophic.

Dear Bruce - I have no doubt there are many who would agree with your recommendations. And your passion is entirely understandable. Unfortunately, the very learned folks in war colleges and in universities across the globe will tell you that comparing Islamic extremists to the governments of Germany and Japan during WWII is incorrect.  Those were actual nation-states, organized governments waging war for territory and control of resources. ISIS, Al Qeada etc are violent religious extremists who see their conflict as a holy war; they wish to draw the West and all governments into exactly the kind of perpetual global war you advocate.  We kill thousands of them, thousands more will step up. No, the real war we need to lead is one on ignorance and relgious extremism by vigorously attacking their root: poverty.  The United States is living proof that stable societies can be created when people are not constantly dwelling at the bottom of Maslow's pyramid of needs. We need to build a global middle class, through the process of conscious capitalism. Only then we extemists die off, because they will not be welcomed or tolerated anywhere.

ISIS, by its actions and words has declared war on the United States of America.  It is no different than with Japan in 1941 and AL Qaeda in 2001. Now it is time to unite. It is time for Congress, both Republicans and Democrats to unite in a Declaration of War against these barbarians. It is time for our Commander In Chief to  take command and act.  It is time for America to activate its factories, implement a Draft, strike with both technology of war and boots on the ground until ISIS is destroyed and unconditional surrender is acheived as it was in Japan, as it was when the Allies destroyed Germany.  Then it is time to do a Marshall Plan for the infrastructure destroyed in Iraq and Syria. It will cost. It will take decades. It will be bloody now but less so than later.  This Vietnam Vet who is a liberal Democrat says do it now in their sand box, not later in ours.  I never thought I would say this, much more beleive to be the best option, but suddenly I do.

Not just paper, John.  It is the major growth business along the Somalian coast, or was until the navy SEALs got involved.  The millions for ransom pays for more lucrative kidnappings and hires more kidnappers.  Ask Captain Phillips.

Not just paper, John.  It is the major growth business along the Somalian coast, or was until the navy SEALs got involved.  The millions for ransom pays for more lucrative kidnappings and hires more kidnappers.  Ask Captain Phillips.
Well said.

Name one person who does not believe in the dangers of militant Islam?  Read through the NYT comments on this and related issues and you will find a gallery of temporizers and those who somehow shift the blame for this latest abomination to the United States.

Name one person who does not believe in the dangers of militant Islam?  Read through the NYT comments on this and related issues and you will find a gallery of temporizers and those who somehow shift the blame for this latest abomination to the United States.
The talk of using nukes is bizarre

They will take over Western Europe by infiltrating and crying religious persecution every time they try to isolate themselves, create extremist cells, and not adopt the cultural norms of their new "homeland".  They are doing it already.  It will be a war in the streets one day with hand to hand combat.

How sad that a fine human being such as James Foley was sacrificed. Our government's failed attempt to rescue him
should be made public.

ISIS is the most dangerous terror group in existence. They are backed by malcontents who ultimately want to take over all of Western Europe as well as all Arab countries. Ransom may buy the lives of some captives, but it will not stop these maniacal, bloodthirsty mongrels.

It may be necessary to resort to the use of limited nuclear weaponry to decimate this garbage. A few drones will not do it.

I've been listening to this talk Foley gave after he was released from Libya. It's heartbreaking to listen to him talk about those days, how 'it's not worth taking risks that may cost you your life', and about his family.

http://dradis.ur.northwestern.edu/multimedia/audio/events/2011/06/jamesf...

I like this

As disturbing as my position may seem I absolutely agree with a policy of never, NEVER paying ransom. If the Europeans have not been such soft pushovers Mr. Foley might very well be alive today.

At the end of the day the game is all about money, isn't it?
